newsitem.title: INDIA: India call ends down, gilt yields continue to rise.
newsitem.headline: India call ends down, gilt yields continue to rise.

text.p: Indian call money rates eased after opening high while gilt yields continued to firm up in moderate trade on Wednesday, dealers said.
Call money ended around 10 percent, down from the day's opening 10.50-10.75 percent, they said. Stray deals were also reported below 10.0 percent, they said.
"Call money rates eased on lack of demand," a dealer at a foreign bank said. Dealers said call money was likely to trade around the same levels for the next week.
"Repos deals struck today were in the region of 10.15 percent," a dealer said. "This may be an indication of the call money rates for the rest of the reporting fortnight."

Yields on government securities continued to move up in moderate trade, dealers said. "At the moment, there are no buyers in the market," a dealer said. "With call looking firm, market participants are unwilling to take positions."
The 13.50 percent 1997 government of India stock was traded on Wednesday at a yield of 13.45 percent, up from 13.38 percent on Tuesday, dealers said.
Yield on the 13.62 percent 1998 stock moved up marginally to 13.63 percent from 13.60 percent, they said.
Dealers said there were no trades in commercail paper or certificates of deposit on Wednesday.
Rates on inter-corporate deposits remained steady in the 17-19 percent range for top-rated borrowers.
